title: William B. Hartsfield
text:
William Berry Hartsfield Sr. (March 1, 1890 – February 22, 1971), was an American <a href="politician">politician</a> who served as the 49th and 51st <a href="List%20of%20mayors%20of%20Atlanta">Mayor of Atlanta, Georgia</a>. His tenure extended from 1937 to 1941 and again from 1942 to 1962, making him the longest-serving mayor of his native <a href="Atlanta%2C%20Georgia">Atlanta</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>.
Early career.
Hartsfield entered politics in 1922 by winning a city <a href="alderman">alderman</a> seat. He served two terms in the <a href="Georgia%20House%20of%20Representatives">Georgia House of Representatives</a> during the 1930s.
Mayor of Atlanta.
William B. Hartsfield was first elected <a href="Mayor%20of%20Atlanta">Mayor of Atlanta</a> in January 1937. Upon taking office, the city was $3 million in debt, due to the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>. Hartsfield quickly turned around the city's finances, but lost re-election in 1940. The man who defeated Hartsfield served just one year as mayor, before being drafted into the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>. Hartsfield won election in 1941, and remained in office until 1961.
In an obituary for him, <a href="the%20New%20York%20Times">the New York Times</a> credited Hartsfield with developing Atlanta into a national aviation center. He has also been credited for ensuring a good water supply with the completion of the <a href="Lake%20Lanier">Buford Dam</a>.
Hartsfield received an honorary degree in Doctor of Laws from <a href="Oglethorpe%20University">Oglethorpe University</a> in 1961.
Race.
The New York Times called Hartsfield a "racial moderate", highlighting his slogan "Atlanta is a city too busy to hate", which he often repeated during the <a href="Civil%20rights%20movement">civil rights</a> struggles of the 1950s. In 1957, he won election to his last term as mayor by defeating the staunch segregationist and future <a href="governor%20of%20Georgia">Governor</a> <a href="Lester%20Maddox">Lester Maddox</a>.
Throughout much of the 1940s, Hartsfield pushed for Atlanta to <a href="Municipal%20annexation">annex</a> a number of predominantly <a href="White%20people">white</a> <a href="suburb">suburb</a>s, fearing that Atlanta's "<a href="Negro">Negro</a> population is growing by leaps and bounds", resulting in the loss of "white territory inside Atlanta", and hoped that the inclusion of these suburbs would prevent the city's <a href="black">black</a> population from becoming a "potent political force in Atlanta". While residents of these suburbs rejected annexation in a 1947 referendum, legislation was passed which annexed these communities in 1952, tripling Atlanta's area, and adding 100,000 new residents to the city.
Legacy.
<a href="Willie%20B.">Willie B.</a>, a <a href="gorilla">gorilla</a> that became a popular attraction at <a href="Zoo%20Atlanta">Zoo Atlanta</a> for decades, was named for Hartsfield.
<a href="Hartsfield%E2%80%93Jackson%20Atlanta%20International%20Airport">Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport</a> is named in Hartsfield's honor as well as a later mayor, <a href="Maynard%20Jackson">Maynard Jackson</a>, who led the modernization of the airport in the 1970s.
